speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: We will hear argument next this morning in Case 13-1211, Hana Financial v. Hana Bank. Mr. Hughes.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: But infringement is a question for the jury, right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: If it is, then why wouldn't tacking be in the same category?  Why aren't they -- Alderson Reporting Company they're similar.  In -- in infringement, you ask whether they're confusingly similar.  Tacking has a more demanding standard, but it's the same type of inquiry. So if one is for the jury, why wouldn't the other be for the jury?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: So -- so under your view, a district court's finding they  are reviewed in the court of appeals de novo?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: In this case, the key issue would be reviewed de novo.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: So isn't the key issue the commercial impression of -- and meaning how these marks were used and the commercial impression?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: I'm sorry.  I lost you a little bit.  Why -- why is it going to be a very Alderson Reporting Company different type of result?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Is the jury going to be instructed in any way on what you just told us was the reason we should view those as differently?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Wouldn't there be evidence or instruction on, you know, consumer impression, you have to take into account what happened between these two marks?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: It seems to me that it's rather critical to the contrast you draw.  I mean, what you're saying is the jury might get it right or the jury might get it wrong, and I would say, well, the Federal Circuit maybe got it right or the Federal Circuit got it wrong.  But in terms of what the factual issues are going to be, and those would include what's happening between the two marks, it seems to me the jury has got information just the way the Federal Circuit.  I don't see the difference between the two other than you think -- you think the one result is right and the other would be wrong.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, why doesn't the -- it seems to me the question for the jury is -- is not whether they look alike, but whether they create the same commercial impression.  And it seems to me the instructions to the jury would say these are the two marks, now what you ought to know is that after the Alderson Reporting Company first mark there was a competitor who came into commerce called American Paging, and then the mark was changed from American Mobile Phone to American Mobile Phone Paging. Do you think that that second mark creates a different commercial impression than the first one? And I think a jury would say, heck, yes.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Well, but suppose that an important part of the case was that when American Paging came along for a few years everybody in the United States knew that. The first mark, not many people knew about it. That it seems to me would be critical to the tacking inquiry, and that the consumer's knowledge, the consumer's expertise, in knowing how consumers behave, how consumers think is -- is immensely valuable.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: And if it's viewed as a question of fact?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Are there any facts that you think a jury could determine here or should determine in this kind of a case, in a tacking case?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: How is the judge supposed to know that, what a consumer's impression would be generally?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Just to figure it out?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Some evidence would have to be presented to him or her, right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: I thought the Court said if we're trying to type these things, claim construction is construction of a written instrument.  That's the kind of thing --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: -- that judges do all the Alderson Reporting Company time. But to determine whether there is -- whether the magic words, "same continuing commercial impression to consumers," then the one's that's better equipped to make that determination are people who are consumers, not jurists.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: It's almost every hornbook statement of it is -- quotes that language. Even the Federal Circuit case that goes your way said that that -- that is, the question is whether the old and new mark convey the same continued commercial impression to consumers.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Well, aural or visual appearance, shouldn't that also -- aural and visual to whom? To the people likely to buy these products, not Alderson Reporting Company to the judge.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: As I understand your brief, you say, no, the test really isn't same continuing commercial impression to consumers.  You are Alderson Reporting Company saying it's the scope of -- the scope of the old and the new, and you can't use tacking to expand what the old would have meant.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But if the answer to that is that of course you can't; if you are saying that the old one was the first use, then whatever the scope of the old one is, is it, and you can't add to it because of what you did later.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Well, why -- wait. Explain why I was wrong in saying all they have to know is what was the scope of the original mark, the one that counts?  The later change can't expand what was the original.  So that seems to answer what you say -- you seem to say, this same continuing commercial, that's not it.  It's what is the scope of the old mark and what is the scope of the new mark.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: And if the answer is that the new mark can't go beyond the scope of the old, that's the -- that's the end of that inquiry.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But what I -- what I was trying to suggest is you would never get to what the second mark scope is because what the scope of the first one is determinative.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Again, if I could just -- what is it that you think a jury could not be instructed on in addressing that same consideration?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Do you think consistency appears in the -- in the judicial opinions that have treated this as a question of law?  I mean, what -- what is the judge -- does he get cases and look at -- look at what other cases have said is tackable and what isn't tackable?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, I guess the stare decisis point is -- is minimized, though, if you appreciate the fact that these marks are -- each one is sort of sui generis.  I mean, I don't know what precedential value I can get from looking at, you know, the dolphin changes on page 50 by the fact that there is a case about the Loctite Corporation behind.  I mean, I'm sure some are similar, but it seems to me that each one is -- is significantly different, so I don't know the significance of the stare decisis in this context.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Even -- even the ones you -- you point us to do -- do not impress me as establishing any kind of -- look on page 50, dolphin to dolphin, and the second dolphin is stylized in -- in cursive writing, right?  And that is upheld as -- as tackable.  Then on the next page, on 51, the second one from the bottom, it -- it's the opposite progression, turbo in cursive goes to turbo in -- in capital letters and that is not permitted.  I cannot for the life of me decide why the one should be permitted and the other should not be permitted.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: And I'd much rather blame it on the jury than on the court. (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: The problem there for you which is although those older cases were at a time when equity and law were separated and there were no rights to jury trials in equity.  So once that distinction was done away with, you don't have the plethora of cases that you --

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: And you don't know how many of those cases the parties agreed to a bench trial.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Well, I doubt very much those -- in those earlier cases that lawyers were thinking of consumer reports and pictures and videos and all the other things they present today.  I agree with you.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: So the cases were simple by their nature back then.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. Mr. Van Den Bosch.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Why don't you deal with the example that the Chief Justice presented of the American Packing Company or that was discussed Alderson Reporting Company earlier.  What would the jury do with that knowledge?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: It can be taken away from the jury you're saying?  If -- if no jury could possibly find tacking appropriate, the Court could issue Alderson Reporting Company a judgment as a matter of law.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Of course you -- you need some predictability for a judge for disallow a jury verdict as a matter of law, right.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I mean, you've got to admit there is some predictability.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, you emphasize that the consumer perspective is what's important, but Alderson Reporting Company there are other aspects of tacking as well that seem more suited to a court than to a jury.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: If we -- when we write this opinion, will we have to have in the back of our minds what effect it will have on likelihood of confusion, the likelihood of confusion issue?  Is -- is there some way that we should treat this as quite -- quite discrete from that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: I -- I recognize that.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Is it the elephant in the room or something like that?  I don't know what --

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: -- The metaphor is?  --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: What about the point that the question really is what was the scope of each -- what was the scope of the original mark and the later one?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: What about obviousness in patent law?  That' -- that, I take it, is also a legal -- legal issue.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Are there any of the features that your friend says have to go to the court that you think could not be addressed in jury instructions?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Would you repeat what you said about the -- the other defenses, laches and what else?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: And those are still available on -- on remand?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. Ms. Harrington.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: You're saying essentially that legally equivalent just means equivalent for the purpose of deciding this legal question?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: I'm a little confused about that because there is a plethora of quotations from the case law that tacking should be a limited thing and not expansive and the -- his scope point.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: And how do you communicate that to the jury, because by nature the evidence the jury is going to see is the changed product, and the question in terms of are they going to be confused by it, they're not, because they're going to know it's the same manufacturer.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: That almost suggests to me that a lot of these older cases were decided wrong. Unless the jury knows about how limited this --

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: What part does the judges in setting the boundaries by deciding the question Alderson Reporting Company either on summary judgment or judgment as a matter of law, that -- I -- my thought was that a judge would not let -- that the bounds of the doctrine were decided by the judge when he puts the question to the jury.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KAGAN
speakers.text: I assume the same would be true of likelihood of confusion if that's the argument, right, that the jury serves as a focus group in the same way for that question.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: I'll check it out in my notes.  I thought that there was a split on the likelihood of confusion issue on the point of whether it goes to the judge or the jury.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: If I look confused by your answer, I am.  I'll check it.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Seeing as those courts that think it's an issue of law, they still give it to a jury but then ignore what the jury says?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. Mr. Hughes, you have 6 minutes left.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: Well, let's assume that commercial impression is a jury question, that we were to hold that.  What would be the legal standard that a judge should apply in coming to a legal conclusion?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: What -- what is more -- what is the legal conclusion?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Did you spell that out in your blue brief?  I know that's your -- your yellow brief says this -- everything is wrong up until now because it's a legal question, preemptive scope of the old mark and of the new mark.  That's spelled  out very clearly in your reply brief, but I didn't see it in the blue brief.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOTOMAYOR
speakers.text: The foreign -- the use or reliance on the foreign use of Hana --

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. The case is submitted.
